items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are currently falling but are forecast to rise overnight in response to forecast rainfall.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected until early next week and the situation should continue to improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 14/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but starting to fall on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/10/24, especially in the Thrupp area. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 ,or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high on the River Windrush although they are stabilising and starting to fall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/10/24 especially in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are still high on the River Glyme but are falling very slowly. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on the River Evenlode. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/10/24, especially in the Woodstock area. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning. River levels are expected to remain high on the River Glyme for the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning, 13/10/24, especially in the Abingdon area. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and remain sensitive to further rainfall. . We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains especially in the Hannington Bridge area. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and the river levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thame following recent rainfal. River levels are falling upstream of Thame. Downstream of Thame river levels are still high but steady. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/10/24 especially in Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester. Sunday should be mostly dry with rain forecast overnight into Monday morning. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Water levels are high, but steady, at the Sherborne Lake gauge on the River Yeo. However, river levels are forecast to rise overnight as a result of rainfall this evening.

Flooding may affect locations near the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Property flooding is not expected.

The weather is expected to become more unsettled over the next few days. Rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tonight but clearing through Monday morning.
 
We are monitoring river levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 4PM on Monday 14/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Sunday 13 October. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 23 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 15 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow 14/10/2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are reducing on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Saturday 12th October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

The forecast indicates dry weather for tomorrow, with levels starting to decrease on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and will remove this alert when the risk has reduced.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Sunday 13th October, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 14/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Sunday 13th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Monday 14th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 7.71 m and steady. The drain level is 6.8 m and falling steadily. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3 m.
 
River levels have fallen but some water remains on the moors, and low lying land and roads may still be under flood water, so this flood alert remains in force.

We continue to pump at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations and are using the Parrett Relief Channel to further reduce river levels. We continue to maximise pumping operations to clear as much water off the moors as possible.

The weather is expected to become more unsettled over the next few days. Rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tonight, clearing through Monday morning.
 
We continue to monitor the situation closely. Do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water, and be careful using footpaths near local watercourses and flooded areas. Refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures.
 
This message will be updated by 4PM tomorrow, Monday 14/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
